testing libraries let's take a step back and look at the entirety of
browser testing well we have different types of tests we can test from here down and to end
tests or we can test this api maybe we're hitting a rest api or a graphql api
we can test this service and by service i mean a non-functional a non-ui component
so let me explore this code and validate that it works maybe a unit test does this really well
test this component now i have some user experience type of things where i want to click buttons and i want to validate that this
component works but i don't necessarily need the dependencies the inner components or the services so
i may choose to mock those dependencies and i want to test that this works in this browser
with html5 we've kind of gotten away from browsers making up their own things but
does this javascript blow up in that older version of this browser these are kind of areas of places to
test i want to test in this browser i want to test components i want to test units i want to test apis and i want to
do end-to-end tests to validate everything works there are different tools that fit into
each of these categories and i may choose each of these categories
when i'm trying to test that particular thing so for example if i want to do a unit
test i'll choose mocha or mocha with chai or i'll choose jest
and those are great choices for being able to do these unit tests
unit test s services in the browser karma is a really good way of hosting
unit tests inside various browsers so i can run it inside chrome i can run it inside
firefox i can run it inside edge and i can validate my unit tests will run
in each platform if i'm looking for component tests i'll spin up test utils test utils has a
mechanism for both angular react and view and so i can start to host my components inside of a
unit test that will allow me to shallow render the component tree for example or push
particular buttons and be able to validate that my components behave the way i expect
i'm still in unit test land when i want to test an api i probably don't need a browser at all i
can just fire requests at it and at that point supertest is a perfect tool
supertest allows me to hit this api with requests and validate that the
response is what i need it to be i'm looking at status codes i'm looking at headers i'm looking at body i may
deserialize that body using the mechanism that i need super test is great for that and i don't need
a browser at all for end-to-end tests i have a lot of options
selenium cypress test cafe playwright let's double-click into this end-to-end
test and dig into each piece selenium selenium is really the big dog
in this space and it's the oldest of these techniques selenium and webdriver have become
standards and are baked into most browsers i also have mechanisms for
writing these tests in many languages and frameworks there's also a plugin into firefox where
i can record my tests where a non-technical user can just click through the application
and record all those steps now those aren't the best tests but these are great options
on the downside selenium is a java based server and it really can't integrate very well
into the browser at best it is pushing buttons now that's cool but it also means that
it can't for example wait for browser events and so i do a lot of weighting inside selenium
tests let me wait another second in selenium tests we might have fragile brittle things where i didn't
wait quite long enough this time so now i'll wait two seconds or three seconds
now my tests take a really long time to run not because it took that long to do all
the functionality but because i didn't know how long it was going to take so i had to wait a little bit longer each time selenium
cypress takes a different approach cypress is a browser plugin that digs in deep
into the particular browsers because of this they need integration into each browser and so right now we
have chrome and firefox but they're working on other ones as well like safari
because i have deep integration into the browser i can do things like waiting for dominance when this ajax
request finishes then continue on with the rest of the test there aren't sleeps or weights inside
cyprus tests because i can just wait for this thing to happen that makes my tests a whole lot faster
and a whole lot less brittle that is really cool on the downside
cyprus has a jquery like api and it has promises but they don't quite work the way
promises work in most instances and so it feels a little weird but cyprus has this great
mechanism of recording videos and screenshots at various places if i choose to
and so i can watch a movie of my test run and see exactly where it failed and what
it was doing at the time that can be great when i'm running in a headless environment and the only result
i got is well it didn't pass that's cool cyprus also just came out
with cypress studio and that is cool test cafe
test cafe was powered is powered by devexpress it has that similar browser plugin type
of experience it uses css selectors so it probably feels a little bit more native
when you're writing those selectors than cypress but it has a really odd assertion in
syntax where cyprus is built on mocha and chai test cafe is a unique thing unto itself
so you may find that that assertion syntax is kind of weird in test cafe the tests
don't run in the browser but rather we marshal data back and forth between the browser
and the test runtime environment so there's interesting things like well let me run this code in the browser to
be able to return that back to my test testcafe is focused on running in all
the browsers and so you'll get great browser support for a test cafe
playwright playwright is a brand new one here on this list it's sponsored by microsoft and written
by the developers who built puppeteer so like puppeteer it feels a lot
like a puppeteer-like experience we have apis in javascript typescript python c
sharp go they've really made it accessible much like selenium and it feels a lot like puppeteer so if
you're comfortable with puppeteer you can be really comfortable with playwright
on the downside puppeteer wasn't meant to be a browser testing library and playwright
kind of feels like assertions were bolted on at the end as well um it it just feels weird
similarly to test cafe the test context and the browser context are different
so you may spend some time marshaling data back and forth between the browser and the test runner now we
did that in puppeteer as well so that may feel very natural if you're using playwright

another best practice in this application we didn't have a login experience but you don't want to
do a login at the beginning of every test that's probably slower than you want it
to do instead at the beginning of all tests
go hit an api and grab an authentication token save that authentication token and
leverage it at the beginning of each test now that authentication token will get
